PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; use extra sheets or paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

2. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

11. Generally not interested. But Father said what we might go farther (not worse).

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Walter Bro. James, Dan, Archie McDonald, Thomas

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Darktown. We heard a lot about when R.R. came. Wh

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

None in particular. We received no direction or guidance from any. Didn't know if was semi-farial. Probably all burned over. Have (or didn't know) the old hutsites old and new. Didn't know how grass my first land back at Clapout Bay. Didn't know how to all hand to get started. Didn't know how to cultivate a homestead.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the old Royal Hotel. Owned by mayor Hamilton. Bought of his home. Boarded. Shortly after sight of us bought.

16. How long did you stay there?

Two weeks. When we got there, we went to hospital.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I have always farmed here, still do. Was a boy in the dark. Around 1900 of homesteaders. Made a good crop. The very few that did not make it lost it all.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How did you come?

My Father owned. He worked out considerably on farms in the woods. After coming west, I went to work on lumber camps out of Prince Albert around 50 miles N.W. Went in fall, didn't come out till spring.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

By family and friends. But Father said what we might go farther and worse.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With Bro. James, Dan, Archie McDonald, Thomas

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train called after him, later when R.R. came, Wh

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

None in particular. No received no instructions or guidance from any. Didn't know where to go.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the old Royal Hotel. Owned by my family.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

With two brothers, about 125 miles north.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I have always farmed here, still do. Was a clerk in the dark around 1900 at homestead office, made a good living.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How often did you work?

My Father owned 1100 acres but only worked on farms in the woods. After coming west, I went to Lumber camps out of Prince Albert around 50 miles N.W. Hunt in fall, didn't come out till spring.

19. What was your occupation before coming to Western Canada?

Old work at homestead farms before going to farm.

any ways. Keeping order easy. As good class people

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have?

Purple homesteaded here. Coming from many places, many walked life, many should not have come at all. All came to work ahead of the R.R.'s as we spent too much time on the train. Previously in the 30's, most of the house stayed as families and lost the last of their land. The morale and effort to work was very high.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Many left, many returned. Many left for better opportunities. Many returned for family reasons.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was active in many community activities. Amy got help from the county school board. I was president of our local co-op for many years. On our family church and school as a boy while in early years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Kerrvood was named after a Robert Kerr who once worked for the B.P.R. The Algoma School district was chosen from three names sent in by the trustees. Algoma District #1 is where my family came from. Paul Miller who homesteaded the land.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have?

People immigrated here. Coming from many places, many souls of life. Many should not have come at all. All came to get ahead of the R.R.'s so we spent too much time on the train previously.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

The 30's was most hard times. I stayed as a child and lost my parents. My family went to work in the mines. We moved to a new place. A few did go to good parts of Kansas alone until a few did go to good parts.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was active in many community activities. I was President of our local Co-Op for many years. On our Baptist Church Board of Directors for many years.

(School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in name since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Kirrobert was named after a Robert Kerr who once worked for the B.R. The Alberta School also built was named from their names sent in by the trustees. Alberta was in Alberta when my came from Kendalldale. It was called after Paul Miller who homesteaded the land.
